column1: Roseburg is a city in the U.S. state of Oregon. It is in the Umpqua River Valley in southern Oregon and is the county seat and most populous city of Douglas County. Founded in 1851
column4: making it the principal city of the Roseburg
column5: Oregon Micropolitan Statistical Area. The community developed along both sides of the South Umpqua River and is traversed by Interstate 5. Traditionally a lumber industry town
column6: Roseburg is the original home of Roseburg Forest Products
column7: which is now based in nearby Springfield.

column1: Waterfalls near Roseburg include Susan Creek Falls and Fall Creek Falls. Roseburg's primary industries include timber and tourism
column2: and the region is home to many vineyards and more than 30 wineries.

column1: Oregon Department of Fish & Wildlife lists more than 50 areas for fishing for salmon
column4: bluegill and trout in the Roseburg area.

column1: Modern-day Roseburg is located on the former lands of numerous Indian tribes
column2: including the Cow Creek Band of the Umpqua Tribe
column3: whose Cow Creek Umpqua Indian Foundation is located in Roseburg. Roseburg was the site of the 1855 Hungry Hill battle
column4: part of the Rogue River War of 1855–56
column5: fought between several southern Oregon Indian groups and the US Army.The city was named for settler Aaron Rose
column6: who established a homestead within the current city limits on September 23
column7: 1851. Rose was born in 1813 in Ulster County
column9: he came to Oregon from Coldwater

column1: Rose constructed the first building in what would become Roseburg
column2: a rough structure made of poles and clapboards with a front room about 16 or 18 feet square; it was used as a grocery store
column3: backed by a dining room and kitchen. Originally
column4: guests could use the floor of the front room to spread their beds or were able to sleep out of doors under nearby oak trees. His first structure served as a roadside inn and tavern for many years. Rose built a proper hotel in 1853. He died in 1899.

column1: Roseburg was first known as Deer Creek because it was at the confluence of Deer Creek and the South Umpqua River. In 1854
column2: voters chose Roseburg as the county seat over rival town Winchester. Rose donated 3 acres (1.2 ha) of land and $1
column3: 000 for the building of the county courthouse
column4: and the important buildings of Winchester were moved to Roseburg before 1860.Deer Creek post office was established in 1852
column5: and the name changed to "Roseburgh" in 1857. The spelling was changed to "Roseburg" in 1894. Roseburg was incorporated by the Oregon Legislative Assembly on October 3

column1: The fortunes of Roseburg grew with the lumber industry. In 1937
column2: Roseburg Lumber opened. Founded by Kenneth Ford
column3: the company became the major employer in the community. Other major employers
column4: including Weyerhaeuser
column5: Champion and Sun Studs also developed and grew during this time. By the 1970s Roseburg branded itself as the Timber Capital of the Nation.

column1: Country singer Johnny Cash mythologized Roseburg loggers in the 1960 song  "Lumberjack”:

Ride this train to Roseburg, Oregon. Now there's a town for you!
You talk about rough...
You know a lot of places in the country claim Paul Bunyon lived there.
But you should have seen Roseburg when me and my daddy come there.
Every one of them loggers looked like Paul Bunyon to me.” 


=== Roseburg Blast ===
On August 7, 1959, at approximately 1:00 a.m., the Gerretsen Building Supply Company caught fire. Firefighters soon arrived at the building, near Oak and Pine Streets, to extinguish the fire. Earlier in the evening, a truck driver for the Pacific Powder Company, George Rutherford, had parked his explosives truck in front of the building, which was not noticed. The truck exploded at around 1:14 a.m., destroying buildings in an eight-block radius and severely damaging 30 more blocks.The truck was loaded with two tons of dynamite and four-and-a-half tons of the blasting agent nitro carbo nitrate. Rutherford had parked the truck after arranging his delivery for the following morning, despite warnings given to the Pacific Powder Company two days earlier not to leave such trucks unattended or park them in congested areas". A police officer named Donald De Sues and the Chief of Police were on site and managed to evacuate citizens from the area of the truck before the explosion. Donald De Sues and the Chief of Police were recognized as heroes that day and were both killed in the blast. A total of fourteen people died in the blast and fire
column2: and 125 were injured. Damage was estimated at 10 to 12 million dollars; the powder company was eventually made to pay $1.2 million in civil damages
column3: but was acquitted of criminal wrongdoing.Roseburg's downtown was rebuilt
column4: primarily by businesses using money collected from insurance claims. The city built a new bridge over the South Umpqua River on parcels affected by the disaster. Since the incident
column5: it is commonly referred to as the Roseburg Blast or simply "The Blast". In 2005
column6: SOPTV produced a documentary examining the Blast and the experiences of those who were involved or witnessed it
column7: entitled The Roseburg Blast: A Catastrophe and Its Heroes.

column3: students at Umpqua Community College near Roseburg were attacked by a 26-year-old gunman that had recently moved to the area from Southern California
column4: who killed nine people (eight students and an assistant professor) and injured nine others. The gunman
column6: committed suicide following a gun battle with police. This was the second school shooting in the Roseburg area
column7: the other being a 2006 shooting at Roseburg High School. On October 9
column8: President Barack Obama privately visited families of victims of the shooting. Hundreds of local residents protested the visit due to Obama's support of gun control legislation. In 1968
column9: Bobby Kennedy had given a speech in Roseburg advocating for gun control for the mentally ill and for those with a "long criminal record" of murder.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 10.20 square miles (26.42 km2)
column3: of which 10.01 square miles (25.93 km2) is land and 0.19 square miles (0.49 km2) is water.Roseburg's elevation is approximately 500 feet (150 m). Its highest point is Mount Nebo
column4: a 1
column5: 200-foot (370 m) hill to the west of Interstate 5. Through the 1980s
column6: it was known for its band of 10-20 feral angora goats. Residents said they could predict the weather by watching where the goats were on the mountain; if they were high
column7: the weather would be good. If rain was pending
column8: the goats moved to lower levels. Because the goats wandered across the freeway for grazing
column9: they were a risk to traffic. In the 1980s
column10: they were rounded up and placed for adoption.

column1: Roseburg has a Mediterranean climate (Köppen Csb borderline with Csa) with cool
column4: with a mean temperature of 42.5 °F or 5.8 °C
column7: with a mean temperature of 71.5 °F or 21.9 °C
column8: is the warmest. In a typical year
column9: there are 27 days where the temperature reaches or exceeds 90 °F or 32.2 °C
column10: and two days with a temperature of or above 100 °F or 37.8 °C. Conversely
column11: the temperature drops to 32 °F (0 °C) or below 28 times per annum. The record high temperature is 109 °F (42.8 °C)

column17: and by the 1981 to 2010 average only 28 mornings fall below freezing.

column2: the area has little or no precipitation and plentiful sunshine — on average
column4: August and September are at least partly sunny. There is also a much higher degree of diurnal temperature variation than in the winter. On the other hand
column5: the majority of winter days are overcast and rainy — during this period
column6: rainfalls of 8 inches (200 mm) per month are not uncommon
column7: with as much as 15.74 inches (399.8 mm) during the record wet month of December 1955. Roseburg averages 30.7 inches (779.8 mm) of rain per year
column8: more than half of which falls between November and January. The wettest "rain year" has been from July 1955 to June 1956 with 50.29 inches (1
column9: 277.4 mm) and the driest from July 2000 to June 2001 with only 18.43 inches (468.1 mm).

column1: Light dustings of snow can sometimes be seen
column2: but accumulations are rare. The most snowfall in a month is 23.4 inches (0.59 m) in January 1950
column3: but no other month has had even 8 inches (0.20 m).

column1: Primary and secondary public education in Roseburg are provided by the Roseburg School District. Umpqua Community College is the city's two-year college.
The unemployment rate in Roseburg is about 6.9 percent. During the Great Recession of 2009
column2: the unemployment rate peaked at 16.5% before falling.  The largest employer in the town is Roseburg Forest Products. With 1
column4: Mercy Medical Center is the second largest employer in Roseburg.

column2: the City of Roseburg opened its own library. Previously
column3: the city's library had been part of the Douglas County Library System but was closed when county libraries lost public funding.

column1: There are three newspapers serving Roseburg. The News-Review is published six days per week and is based in Roseburg.  The Roseburg Beacon is published weekly and serves Roseburg.  The Douglas County News is published weekly and is based in the nearby town of Sutherlin.
Oregon Route 99 runs through downtown Roseburg as the main north–south arterial. Interstate 5 runs along the west side of the city
column2: across the South Umpqua River from downtown.

column1: Oregon Route 138 runs northwest from Roseburg to Elkton
column3: and generally east from Roseburg to its terminus at a junction with U.S. Route 97
column4: just east of Diamond Lake and Crater Lake.

column2: Marion E. Carl Memorial Field at the north end of town and George Felt Airport to the west.

column1: Greyhound closed its Roseburg location. The Central Oregon and Pacific Railroad freight railway runs through Roseburg.
Roseburg and surrounding communities are served by U-Trans (formerly Umpqua Transit)
